item.description:
Space Gremlins is a 2-4 player light collaborative-push-your luck game.

You play as gremlins who have boarded a space ship and are now competing to see who can cause the most damage without bringing the ship down. You will move around, chewing wires, pushing buttons, causing power outages, door failures, activating special rooms, and drawing the attention of the crew over 10 turns of chaos. In the end you will all be vented into space and the Gremlin who did the most damage will win!

Erie Railroad is a railroad stock game set around Lake Erie in northwestern Pennsylvania. The game is for 3-5 players and lasts about 30 minutes.

The players take the roles of Industrialists - like William Henry Vanderbilt - who have hidden interests in railroads and try to maximize their profits. The players try to make the most money by auctioning shares of the different railroad companies and by paying out dividends at the right moment to get the most money out of the company. The player with the most money at the end of the game is the winner.

Released as part of Winsome Games's 2013 Essen collection.

User Summary

The The Quest for Piptwynn's Scroll is a tabletop miniatures game that pits two players against each other to obtain Piptwynn's Scroll, an artifact of great importance, that can be found on the top of Star Snag Crag. The object of the game is to reach the top of the Crag, retrieve the Scroll, and then make it off the Crag again. The game board is defined as a series 49 four inch squares arranged in four tiers. The top tier is the peak of Star Snag Crag.

Each player controls a team, or Quad, made up of 4 different specialists, selected from the 8 possible types listed in the game. Some types focus on mobility, others on combat, and some, like the Beastmastr [sic], level the playing field with unusual abilities. These character types also rely on items (magical & non-magical) to give them an edge in certain situations.

Each turn the players perform game actions in a set order of phases: Activation, Movement, Exploration and Occurrences (weather effects or wandering monsters), Conflict Resolution, and Evening (a time of healing and recharging). Both players act simultaneously so occasionally members of one Quad will end up in conflict with each other quite by accident. Random game elements can also send creatures or primitives to attack members of a Quad. Terrain effects are randomly determined the first time the member of a Quad enters a new square. These effects can produce anything from a Refreshing Spring to a Dragon Nest.

Unlike most miniatures game, death isn't a feature of Piptwynn's Scroll. When one side wins a conflict, the other side is driven away. Since this is fundamentally a race to the peak of Star Snag Crag, getting pushed back on any given turn can make the difference between winning and losing. In this way the game is more family-friendly than the many miniatures games that focus on death and dismemberment.

The rulebook also contains several rules variants, including set up a larger board for tournament play. Also included are reproducible sheets, charts, tokens, etc., along with tips on how to paint miniatures and how to build a proper three-dimensional game board. (Players must provide their own miniatures, a playing surface--which can be simple map or more traditional war game terrain, and a set of polyhedral dice)

There were several planned follow-up games for this title, including an RPG crossover. None of them seem to have ever come to fruition.

Target game with 6 targets, all characters from the Noddy books. The targets are all standing and there is an arch between their legs.

Each player gets a 'plastic straw' and there is a plastic ball. Place the targets at one end of the table. Players start at the other end.

The idea is to blow the ball through an arch and thus score points. The winner is the player with the most points after an agreed set time has elapsed.

link.value: Eelco Martinus ten Harmsen van der Beek

item.description:
You're one of the lucky robot factory workers invited to an exclusive event. Your job? Picking refurbished or out-of-date parts to build robots that meet eager buyers' requirements. Sell your completed robots to earn points and achieve certain bonuses to earn even more points — but hurry because other players may be building a robot to sell to the same buyer first. Can you outsmart your opponents and assemble a four-wheeler robot with two heads, or a robot with six eyes and four hands before they do?

In Robots on the Line, robot parts move down two conveyor belts. Players take turns pulling robot parts (heads, bases, arms, hands, batteries, antennas and magnets). Not all robot parts can be taken, however. The line you're pulling from must be switched to ON. Robot parts that aren't taken will be discarded onto the junk pile. Players can pay a dollar to go through the junk pile or they can pay a dollar to turn ON/OFF switches. As players take robot parts, they build robots in front of them. Players can build up to four robots in a game. Trading is always allowed.

To finish a robot it must have a torso, a head, and a base with all other segments off the torso ended with the other parts. While you're building, you'll want to look to the buyers to meet their requirements. A requirement might be a robot with four eyes, or a robot that has no wheels, or a robot with three hands. If you meet a buyer's requirement, you sell it for money. If you meet the bonuses, like medical, war, or cleaning, you get even more money. The game ends when all tiles are off the line or when a player has built 3 robots. The player with the most money wins.

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
A rather complicated board for the age group that would normally enjoy a Noddy related game.

Each player chooses a character and the associated playing piece. There are 6 face-down counters and when you set off along the track you must take one. Turn it over and that tells you which present you are taking to Noddy's house (example present might be a cake).

The first track to move along is the red one. If you land on white numbered squares, they will help you. If you land on black numbered squares then that will be a hazard. However the game at this point is a little different to normal Goose-type games. When arriving on a hazard square, refer to the list in the rules. Hazards relate to the presents. So, if you were carrying the cake, then a hazard for any other present would not apply.

After reaching the end of the red track, you start moving along the letters that spell Noddy (located in the centre of the board). You must reach the end of the fifth letter Y and then set off on the return journey which will end on the letter N.

Finally you move a long the white circles to Noddy's house. However, on this path there are three circles that feature two colours. If you land on one of these and your counter is one of these two colours, then you have to wait until the player with other colour reaches this circle. That wait could be a long one which might well bore the player affected. I guess the designer wanted to make a game that allowed the back-markers to catch up, which is fair enough.

The winner is the first to arrive at Noddy's house.

link.value: Eelco Martinus ten Harmsen van der Beek

item.description: Spin and move game with stunning box cover art by Mcloughlin Brothers. Travel from leaving the port till home.

REVOLVIQA

RevolvIQa, the revolving game series debuted in Nürnberg Toy Fair 2013. It’s basis is an innovation: playing piece supported revolving mechanism. The supporter is a playing piece onto which a constituted bottom surface in the middle of the revolving device is laid upon. A playing piece supported revolving device can make 6 playing pieces step at once.
RevolvIQa Red and RevolvIQa Blue are two independent games, packed into independent boxes, however these ones are intending to be an overture of revolving game series.
In a RevolvIQa box there are 3 individual games: 2 pcs. revolving puzzle games in varied difficulty levels (1 player) and 1 pc. revolving board game (2 players). Playing adventure and rules are varied, however a.m. structure is the same in both RevolvIQa boxes.
Play with revolving puzzles first:
the basic idea here is to have different coloured balls as a „pixel” of a pic on a playing field. The playing field plate is removable and exchangable. It has a hexagonal shape and it is hole-punched at 37 places in bee-cells pattern. It is to be put onto a basic board having 37 spheric recesses in the same pattern area. After pouring the required balls onto field, revolve until all the coloured balls match with the colours of the graphic. Starting with any ball arrangement results solution! A „Fox” and a „Galaxy” in RevolvIQa Red, a „Parachute” and a „Birthday” in RevolvIQa Blue is available as main theme on graphics of the playing fields.
Play with board games next:
There are equal starting chance arrangements for both players and one after the other order playable games by immediate revolving in both RevolvIQa board games. 
Player wins, who revolves 5 in one row of its chosen coloured balls at first: that’s the board game about in RevolvIQa Red. Defeat arrives as magic touch in most of the cases. It’s name: „COLORICA-5”.
Player wins in board game of RevolvIQa Blue, whose all chosen 4 ferries are able to cross the sea first, or the one, whose opponent can’t revolve rule-wise anymore. It’s wintertime and some areas in the sea is frozen (white balls on the board). Revolving rules: revolve on water only (support on dark blue balls only), at least one of revolving player’s ferries shall change place during revolving action, the opponent’s can be revolved at the same time, but only if opponent’s previous revolving action took place elsewhere. Captivating and exciting. It’s name: „FERRY”.


REVOLVIQA Blue
3 games in the box: Parachute, Birthday, Ferry

Revolving puzzle and board games that are developing creativity and logical and strategic skills for 1 or 2 players, children or adults.

Parachute

Revolving puzzle games that are developing creativity and logical skills for 1 player, children or adults. Revolve so that the colored balls could get into their position!
 
Birthday

Revolving puzzle games that are developing creativity and logical skills for 1 player, children or adults. Revolve so that the colored balls could get into their position!
 
Ferry

Games developing logical and strategic skills for two players. The purpose of the game is that one of the players should get all 4 balls (ferries) of his to the other side by revolving them.

item.description:
REVOLVIQA

RevolvIQa, the revolving game series debuted in Nürnberg Toy Fair 2013. It’s basis is an innovation: playing piece supported revolving mechanism. The supporter is a playing piece onto which a constituted bottom surface in the middle of the revolving device is laid upon. A playing piece supported revolving device can make 6 playing pieces step at once.
RevolvIQa Red and RevolvIQa Blue are two independent games, packed into independent boxes, however these ones are intending to be an overture of revolving game series.
In a RevolvIQa box there are 3 individual games: 2 pcs. revolving puzzle games in varied difficulty levels (1 player) and 1 pc. revolving board game (2 players). Playing adventure and rules are varied, however a.m. structure is the same in both RevolvIQa boxes.
Play with revolving puzzles first:
the basic idea here is to have different coloured balls as a „pixel” of a pic on a playing field. The playing field plate is removable and exchangable. It has a hexagonal shape and it is hole-punched at 37 places in bee-cells pattern. It is to be put onto a basic board having 37 spheric recesses in the same pattern area. After pouring the required balls onto field, revolve until all the coloured balls match with the colours of the graphic. Starting with any ball arrangement results solution! A „Fox” and a „Galaxy” in RevolvIQa Red, a „Parachute” and a „Birthday” in RevolvIQa Blue is available as main theme on graphics of the playing fields.
Play with board games next:
There are equal starting chance arrangements for both players and one after the other order playable games by immediate revolving in both RevolvIQa board games. 
Player wins, who revolves 5 in one row of its chosen coloured balls at first: that’s the board game about in RevolvIQa Red. Defeat arrives as magic touch in most of the cases. It’s name: „COLORICA-5”.
Player wins in board game of RevolvIQa Blue, whose all chosen 4 ferries are able to cross the sea first, or the one, whose opponent can’t revolve rule-wise anymore. It’s wintertime and some areas in the sea is frozen (white balls on the board). Revolving rules: revolve on water only (support on dark blue balls only), at least one of revolving player’s ferries shall change place during revolving action, the opponent’s can be revolved at the same time, but only if opponent’s previous revolving action took place elsewhere. Captivating and exciting. It’s name: „FERRY”.


REVOLVIQA Red
3 games in the box: Fox, Galaxy, COLORICA-5

Revolving puzzle and board games that are developing creativity and logical and strategic skills for 1 or 2 players, children or adults.
Description
Fox

Revolving puzzle games that are developing creativity and logical skills for 1 player, children or adults. Revolve so that the colored balls could get into their position!
 
Galaxy

Revolving puzzle games that are developing creativity and logical skills for 1 player, children or adults. Revolve so that the colored balls could get into their position!
 
COLORICA-5

Games developing logical and strategic skills for two players. The purpose of the game is that one of the players should be able to revolve five balls next to each other, in one line.

Bit Shift is a game of wits and bits. Each playerâ€‹â€‹ gets a handful of cards with a combination of 0's and 1's and must get the central board, which also consists of 0's and 1's, to match the cards in their hand.

Each player takes turns modifying the board to try and either score or try to prevent their opponents from scoring!

City of Fortune is a combination of role selection and worker placement game with a hint of map building. Players take turns selecting roles and placing buildings to collect resources which can be used to gain points based on the roles that were selected. Roles change every round, so the game is constantly changing. There's very little luck involved, which makes this game a deep strategic masterpiece.

2-6 player game, 15-20 minute game play. Players are the bosses of their families in the 1930s gangster era. Players hire thugs, bookies and torpedos to help them gain control of the various rackets in the city. Card play weakens/enhances family strengths during the game. The major twist is the HIT die, played during a racket round, where every character is a target!

Mature themes (nothing you couldn't read about in any Time-Life book from the library), recommended for 12+ years.

From the designer of Battle of the bands, Backstage Pass and Portable Adventures card games.

Players (families) battle each other to control a set number of rackets, 2 of one kind of racket or 3 of any kind racket. You build your family using thug, bookie and torpedo cards, collectively known as mug cards. Their point value is your power during rackets. When a racket card is being fought over, the players all roll a HIT die (1d6); any opponent mugs in play that match your die roll (a die is printed on the mug cards), those cards are either flipped-unusable during this round, or discarded. The die roll is then added to the remaining value of your mugs in play, highest score wins the contract. But, you must have a mug who can control that racket, otherwise it is discarded. Family cards are played during non racket rounds to help your family or hinder the opposition.

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Players are student alchemists, taking turns exploring the academy grounds, obtaining ingredients to make potions. Ingredients come in five types, each type found in a different region of the board, or by drawing random cards.

Play consists of rolling a die to move a pawn around the board, collecting cards from certain spaces. Groups of cards allow you make potions. You need to collect enough potions to win the game, but using the potions during the game gives you powerful advantages.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Leapfrog is an alquerque-style game played on a square board of 97 spaces in a complex pattern. Each player has a Frog King and 8 Frog Pawns and the winner is the first player to get their Frog King to the central space.

Each player on their turn moves one piece a series of "leaps" — each leap being over exactly one occupied or unoccupied space. If the final leap is over a friendly piece then the player must immediately make another move with that piece. If the final leap is over an opponent's piece then the turn passes to that opponent who must make a move with that piece.

Leapfrog was published in issue 7 of the Games and Puzzles Journal.

The game board represents a honeycomb in the bee hive. The queen rests in the middle of the brood nest (brown cells) surrounded by her royal household. The colored cells above the brood nest show stored pollen (inside the pollen field there are yellow and brown pollen cells).
Yet above the pollen field the honey cells are located (yellow cells). The honeycomb is occupied by the queen and several workers and drones. The smallest bees are workers.

In Das Bienenspiel players try to get 3 cards of honey and 3 cards of pollen. This is achieved by reaching either honey or pollen cells and claiming one. After each claim the player pawn has to return to the central brood nest unless he is able to hit a spot with a drone which allows the player to immediately turn around and go for another card.

Players have to move the full roll amount and must not enter cells which are occupied by bees or other player pawns.
Player with the full set of 6 cards (3+3) need to return to the queen cell to win the game.

Objective: score most points hitting 'rolly boys' with a ball (skittle)
 - acting by turns -
5 moveable (rotating) rolly boys (skittles), horizontally mounted on a staff, must be hit by a ball; flip the ball against a skittle (with values from 1 - 5) causing a rotation; achieved numbers should be summed up.
remarks:
typical design of wood working, located in the Erz mountains

Objective: gain as many treasures as possible sailing in dangerous waters - game ends after all treasures are kept by players
 - moving/acting by turns -
each player moves according die roll; if your ship enters the treasure island you may take a treasure - 1 or 2(max) of totally 13 - and sail home; but there are islands and shoals (light blue squares) which block or complicate (less freight) your way home. 
You can get rid of your treasures passing an island, but you may load them onto your ship again with a matching die.

Objective: be the first reaching target space
 - moving by turns -
each player rolls the die moving forward; ending on a marked space follow instructions. 
remarks:
simple "Roll & Move" game with educational elements (beer history)

Objective: be the first forming the letters 'AHA' with 9 small coloured sticks
 - acting by turns -
all players get 9 wooden sticks with the same colour each;
active player rolls the coloured die three times; if your own colour is shown add one stick forming the word 'AHA'. If you got that colour twice within a turn - remove all sticks and start again.
remarks:
should had been published before WWII; confusing cover shows two dice, but none of them - 6d6 & 6dsymbols - is used/added.

Objective: be the first reaching target space (80)
 - moving by turns -
each player rolls the die, moving forward; ending on a marked space follow instructions, additionally read aloud text, originated from the book novelist Wilhelm Busch
remarks:
cute pewter figures
three different editions - 107, 107/1 and 107/2

Objective: be the first to reach target space
 - moving by turns -
A roll-and-move race game portraying an airship journey combine with all possible incidents, even fire => quite impressive: drawing of a parachuter
Ending on (such a) marked space follow instructions.
remarks:
beautiful paintings, pewter figures, large board
should be published ~1910's

This game is played with two deck of cards in where one is the dungeon the other is the village. With a bag of dice the player must roll the dice and with the result gain certain amount of mana,cash,attack,and shields. After the rolls the player must decide to visit de village or go down in the dungeon to fight a monster (classical fantasy dingeon game yes I know). The game ends when 5 Clock cards are out of the decks and the player with more Prestige points wins.

What makes this game unique is it exploits a dice pool of 21 dice and that the level system is based on a poker style achievements. You are allowed to carry 3 cards of each color.
Blue cards are Potions
Red cards are skills and spells
Green cards are Equipment
Yellow cards are Magical Time Artifacts (their power increases has the clock cards show up)

Object of the game:
Be the first arriving at target space (Berlin/73)

Simple 'Roll and Move' game, learning the cities & places of interest of Germany before WWI. Ending on a marked space follow instructions glued on lid inside.
Equipped with pewter figures (cars) and cute drawings game communicates a special feeling of that age/time.

Much like Liar's Dice and other bluffing games, Bull uses 4 sets of cards numbered 1 to 11 as well as 4 Wild Cards and 2 "Bull" cards. Players play cards face down and make an annoucement concerning what those cards are. If someone challenges, then if the player was telling the truth, the challenger takes the cards. If not, the annoucing player keeps the cards. Scoring is based on the value of the cards players take and the lowest score wins.

Set in the world of LEGO's Legends of Chima theme, the CHI Battles game system involves racing two LEGO vehicles — called "speedorz" — against one another to score "chi." If you win the dexterity part of a round, you then draw a card and select the attribute to use for attack. You can optionally spend one chi to add a sum to your score. Your competitor compares their score to yours and the winner claims two chi. The first player to reach six chi wins.

Different LEGO kits add different characters to the system, with their own speedorz, sets of character cards, and different buildable dexterity challenges.

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Join the party with this tongue in cheek card game. Impress the ladies with crazy dances, exotic drinks and cheesy pick-up lines.

Players draw five "move" cards, a mixture of pick-up lines, dances, name-drops and outfits and cock-block cards. Then, players choose a location in the club to "make their move".

Locations include:
The Bar - players may exchange "move" cards for drink cards and play drink cards as well as other move cards.
The Dance Floor - players get a bonus to "dance moves" but cannot play name-drops or pick-up lines.
The VIP - players exchange a move card for entry, but receive a bonus for name drop cards. All other move cards can be played.
The Balcony - players get bonuses to pick-up lines and can play all other move types except dance moves.
The Bathroom - players can draw back up to 5 move cards.

The player who makes the best move, as scored by the total point value of all move cards made that round, impresses the lady that round. The next round, a new lady is eligible to impress, and the game continues until the lady total equals the winning total as determined by the number of players.

Wizard Duel is a card game being played at the 2013 Penny Arcade Expo East. Players join one of 3 schools and roam the convention looking for other wizards to duel, and fight with a deck containing Bolt, Burst and Shield spells. 
When you meet a rival wizard, call out a gravitas-laden challenge that will shake the heavens with it's fury (but not too loud). Each wizard will then select a card from his or her deck and reveal them dramatically at the same time.

A Bolt is a quick spell that strikes first to defeat the more complex Blast.
A Blast effects a large area and will easily circumvent a Shield
A Shield spell creates a wall of force that can ward off any Bolt.

The wizard with the victorious spell is... victorious! If wizards cast the same spell, they strike each other in an explosion that would easily deplete any special effects budget. The wizards then pick a new spell and the duel continues until one is defeated.

The triumphant wizard claims all cards his or her opponent used in the duel. After Pax, the points are tallied and one school is crowned champion!

Objective: be the first reaching target space (Berlin)
 - moving by turns -
simple 'Roll & Move' game; you may choose (depending on the very first die roll) one of 3 different routes (car/Train/plane) to travel to Berlin; ending on a marked space follow instructions.

remarks: 
very cost saving publication (1949!) => map, instructions, slipcase. Instructions reflect typical terms of that time/age like "Interzonen-food stamp" or "delousing"; incidents like 'carrying along a Westgerman newspaper - go back to...' describe daily encounters at the inner German border.
For the purposes of Berlin's 750 year celebration game was republished in 1987.

Ancient ruins of a pyramid were discovered and Huey, Lewey and Dewey along with Dolly are on a mission to dicover the ancient artifacts! Can you help them achive their goal?

Players take turns rolling the dice and they enter the pyramid where they "dig" for treasures in each pile of tiles (using the little cuppings that come with the game) and they stop once they hit a dirt or a a minus tile. Once the pyramid is empty from all the tiles they head back to the finish line and the one with the most points win!

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
A pseudo co-op game that secretly places one player against all their friends.

Much like fabled assassins of old, one player must bide time and patiently wait for the opportune moment to strike. But should your strike fail, or you wait too long, beware the others may notice and your life be now in danger. For the others, however, a perilous fight for survival while the assassin stalks the shadows and his identity remain unknown.

In PERIL, players play cards from their hand to either save or damage the turn player, secretly attempting to identify the assassin and destroy him before he destroys them. But be weary, who you destroy could be one of your own.

A language learning game, designed to study the conjugation of Italian verbs (both regular and irregular). With the 48 tiles the game tells the story of a day in the life of the Grilli family. Each tile has a picture on the left side and a text on the right side. In the text the verbs are all in the infinitive form, and have to be conjugated when the tile is played, but it can be checked in the instructions whether the correct form was used.
All the tiles are numbered. The game starts with the tile number 1 and based on the description tile number 2 needs to be found and so on.
The game can be played solo or in large groups (e.g. Italian classes).

Quiz game about München (Munich) landmarks.

The board is a map of the city, with a track wandering through it. If a player is the first to land on one of the numbered spaces, he draws the card from the deck of 30 cards and reads out the information on the blue side of the card. Then he turns the card over to see what instructions he has to follow. This are fairly predictable; Miss a turn perhaps, roll the die and move backwards, and so on. The player then takes the card and keeps it in front of him where all the players can see it. The card will have a value ranging from 5 to 30, with the value being commensurate with the penalty value of the instruction on it. If a subsequent player lands on a numbered field that has already been taken, then he treats the space as a normal space without number.

When the numbered space 30 has been reached, that player has finished. The others play on. When all the players have reached the 30 space, the 'won' cards are added up and the winner is the one with the most points.

Objective: Be the first moving up to field 68 
- moving by turns -
throw the die and move according rolled number; ending on a any image follow instructions glued on cover inside.

remarks: game belongs to the series: "Scholz' künstlerische Spiele" with very nice graphics/images;
as usual - cute pewter figures
seems to be the predecessor of Von MÃ¼nchen durch Oberbayern nach Tirol

Track down the world's deadliest animals with the Deadly 60 Tracker Board Game. Based on the hit BBC TV show Deadly 60, you'll follow in Steve's footsteps on the trail of the planet's strongest, fastest and toothiest predators. Prowl around the board collecting equipment before heading to the centre for a time challenge - the first to find three deadly beasts wins. The Deadly 60 Tracker Board Game is suitable for two or more players aged eight and up.

This card game is a traditional Quartett game using the picture cards but it also has a second game that uses the backs of the cards. This game is called Catcher Quartett and is only for two players.

Each card has a wrestling move on it.The four moves are Press, Pin, Drop Kick and Body Slam.

Each player is dealt half the deck. Both players choose a card secretly and then both cards are revealed simultaneously. If they are not the same, the following applies:

PRESS beats PIN
PIN beats BODY SLAM and DROP KICK
DROP KICK beats PRESS
BODY SLAM beats DROP KICK and PRESS

The strongest card takes the weaker card. Play continues until all the cards are used and the player with the most cards wins. If you want a longer game you can continue until one player has won all the cards.

This is not a Memory game variation but it does require a good memory to win.

Each player takes a board on which there are a number of circles. Five of these circles show a Pancake Monster. Each player has a quantity of Pancake Tiles and these are placed on your board. The Pancake Monsters must be covered carefully so that the Monster cannot be seen.

in a turn, a player may lift up a Pancake Tile from the player on his left. If it does not reveal a Pancake Monster, the tile is taken and put on your own board. You may then continue your turn by taking a Pancake Tile from the board of the next player to your left. And so on, until a Pancake Monster is revealed. The tile must be replaced and the turn is over. Now the next player can play accordingly.

You need a good memory because it is bad to reveal a monster and as they get revealed and recovered, players should get some idea of which tile not to look under.

The first person to completely fill their board with Pancake Tiles, wins.

A short two player card game designed for 2013 Two-Player Print-and-Play Design Contest

Using 20 cards from a standard poker deck, players take turns trying to sell cards to each other and make a profit. The player selling can put lower value cards up for sale, but they run the risk of getting caught and losing their honest reputation.

Each player faces a small "Prisoner's Dilemma" choice each round. The player selling tries to guess what cards the other player is likely to buy. The player buying cards must decide if the other player is being honest or not.

In Silent But Deadly, there are 10 different types of fart cards in four various colors. Each fart card has a description of the fart card, like "Fluffy Poot", "Eggy Stinker", and "Floating Biscuits". Players discard a card in his/her hand by matching a fart type or by matching the color of the card played. The goal of the game is for a player to discard all of his/her cards.

Additional 'special play' cards include, "Light a Match", "Baked Beans", "Cabbage", and "Silent But Deadly". The Light a Match card negates these three specialty cards: 
--Cabbage card requires a player to the left to pick up 1 card. 
--Baked Beans requires the pick up of 2 cards.
--Silent But Deadly requires picking up 5 cards.

When a player is down to one card, he/she must announce, "low on gas" before the next player discards, else he/she is penalized and must draw 2 cards.

Objective: be the first reaching target space 'E'
- simple 'Roll & Move' game/ moving by turns -
each player moves his/her meeple according die roll

name.value: Axis & Allies Air Force Miniatures: Bandits High

item.description:
Axis & Allies Air Force Miniatures is a fast, action-paced game of World War II air combat. Players take the stick of one or more of history's most famous warplanes, taking on their opponent in wild dogfights. Bandits High features aircraft used in the Pacific Theater of Operations and introduces new scenarios, including bombing missions!

Two-Player Starter Set includes six non-random warplanes, including the exclusive P-38J Lightning Ace, and everything needed to start dogfighting!

Booster Packs each contain three random warplanes, and there are 31 different planes for players to collect!

This is a game of aerial combat with WWII aircraft of various nations fought on a hexagonal map. This set represent aircraft primarily from the early years of the war. Players take turns determining initiative, moving their aircraft, and attacking opponents. Victory is determined player elimination or victory point total comparisons. Optional rules allow for clouds, flak fields, barrage balloons, and even night combat.

A&A Air Miniatures: Bandits High details:

- Set contains legendary aircraft like the Ju 87 Stuka, Navy F4U Corsair, P-51D Mustang, and IL-2 Sturmovik.
- Prepainted, durable plastic—assembled and ready to play, right out of the box.
- Abilities and statistics of units based on historical performance in battle.

link.value: Axis & Allies Air Force Miniatures: Angels 20

name.value: Family Charades In A Box Compendium

item.description:
Family Charades In A Box Compendium is a party and family game of acting out. Six themes of Charades are included in one box. Themes include: Hollywood Charades, Animal Party, Time Capsule, Family Charades, Kids Charades, and Picture Charades (which requires no reading). The goal of the game is to be the first team to win the most points at the end of 12 rounds by correctly guessing the Charade(s).

The Second Edition print of Family Charades In A Box Compendium was manufactured in the United States. Components include six card decks, a sand-timer and a spinner. Each card has three Charades. The spinner determines which Charades the TEAM will act out. Choices on the spinner include acting out one of the three Charades on the card, the OTHER TEAM picking which Charade should be acted out, the TEAM chooses which Charade to act out or all three Charades must be acted out.

Rules include a signal sheet to help players act out the Charade.

Gazala is a low complexity wargame on the Battle of Gazala. The game can be played either solitaire or two player.

Each player has an objective that he or she must meet in order to win - either number of units destroyed or occupying certain hexes. Each counter can move one hex per turn. The combat is a simple system in which the players must roll greater than or equal to the number printed on the counter to achieve a hit.

The rules are only three pages long. The game also includes a counter sheet and a map that can be printed at 11x17 (A3) or 8.5x11 (A4).

2nd El Alemein is a low complexity wargame on the Second Battle of El Alamein. The game can be played either solitaire or two player.

Each player has an objective that he or she must meet in order to win - either number of units destroyed or occupying certain hexes. Each counter can move one hex per turn. The combat is a simple system in which the players must roll greater than or equal to the number printed on the counter to achieve a hit.

The rules are only three pages long. The game also includes a counter sheet and a map that can be printed at 11x17 (A3) or 8.5x11 (A4).

Relic Expedition is a jungle exploration game with a variable board, hand management, collectible treasures, and dangerous wild animals!

The game board starts small, with only a few of the tiles revealed. As players explore the jungle, new tiles are revealed and the board grows in unpredictable ways, making for a completely different game each time. Hidden in the jungle, you'll find six different types of treasures made of six different materials. To win, you must collect four matching treasures — either four of the same type or four of the same material — and fly away from the jungle to victory.

If you hope to travel through the terrain and survive the dangers of the jungle to get that treasure, though, you'll also need supplies like machetes, mountain climbing gear, panther traps, tranquilizer darts, vines, and more. You carry treasures and supplies in your backpack, but your backpack space is limited! As the game progresses, you'll have to choose carefully. As you find more treasure, you'll have to make tough decisions about which supplies you have to leave behind.

link.value: Relic Expedition: Villages and Markets Expansion

item.description:
Shift is an anime themed card game in which players duel using a single card and some coins. Shift cards have stats and Modifiers on all four sides, called Gears. Each card functions like a deck in a traditional CCG, where each Gear is a separate hand. And much like decks in a CCG, each card rewards different strategies and play styles.

Players take turns attacking or shifting their cards to another Gear. To use a Gear's Modifier, you might have to pay a cost; costs may require flipping a coin, or paying spirit - which is earned by taking damage. The first player to deal six damage to their opponent wins!

item.description:
Colovero is an easy trick-takting game.

rules from the publishers homepage:

The player to the left of the dealer is the first to play a card. In clockwise order, all the other players also play a card. Once all players have played their card, the orange and green cards are scored separately. The color with the higher score wins the trick. If the colors tie, the color with the highest individual card wins. If that is also a tie, the color with the highest card played last wins.

If a joker is part of the trick, it wins the trick for its color, no matter what the score is. If both jokers are played, the joker played last wins. The trick goes to the player who played the winning card. The player who won the trick places the trick in front of himself with the winning card face up.

At the end of the round, when all players have played their nine cards, the color that won the most tricks in that round is the winning color.

Players receive one point for each trick of the winning color and lose one point for each trick of the losing color. This total score is the result of this round. The results of the rounds are added up as you keep playing. It is up to the players to decide how many rounds they would like to play. At the end of the game, the player with the highest score wins.

A variant of Tiddlywinks. Three games are described.

Game 1: Normal Tiddlywinks.

Game 2. Place the board flat across the empty box. Each player has six small counters and one big one. A counter is flipped towards the target board which is mostly green but also a slaller white area and a hole in the centre. Each counter can only be flipped once. If you miss the target you score nothing with that counter. If you can get a counter on to the board, score as follows:
Green = 25 points
White = 50 points
In the hole = 100 points.
Play 6 turns each and the one with the best score wins.

Game 3: Use the Goal board. Stand it up on two supports so that it is vertical. Now take turns to flick a counter through the hole. Each goal scored is recorded. After an agreed time or number of turns, the player with the most goals wins.

Experience the legendary leather industry of Ubrique. Play as one of the main leather manufacturing companies and grow from a simple workshop to a leading factory.

Each player begins the game by selecting one of Ubrique's most famous factories. All players begin as modest workshops with a limited workforce. At the start of each turn, two 'market' cards are placed on the board. You may find either an 'order' or an 'event'. Events happen automatically and you will have to follow the instructions on them. As for orders, you may pick one out and begin manufacturing for top international fashion brands. On order cards you'll find how many handbags and wallets need to be made and how much you'll be getting paid when delivered. The bigger the order, the more workforce you'll need. The solution is hiring external workshops. But be careful! There's only a limited amount of workshops in Ubrique, so make sure they're not manufacturing for other players!

Also, in order to manufacture handbags and wallets you'll be purchasing real leather tokens! The more packages you buy, the lower the cost. It's up to you to decide how much you're willing to invest.

Given your limited starting funds and factory size, it's always a good idea to start off with small orders. As the game goes on you'll be able to expand your factory and increase your workforce, requiring less external workshops to complete small orders and making it possible to pick up bigger orders.

In the advanced rules, players may negotiate with each other, trade leather, and share orders - just like in real life.

'El Rey de la Piel' is an educational game that faithfully reflects the leather goods industry, where victory depends mostly on business strategy than luck.

The goal of the game is to expand your factory to the highest level and become the leading factory in Ubrique.

FIVE-OH! Is a card game with a humorous approach towards society’s finest. The “boys in blue”. Collect cards to form units of different types of cops. Solve crimes as they pop up with specific units you have gathered. Watch out, there are action cards also that can change the police force you have so diligently been recruiting! You never know what will come up, just like in real life “on the beat”.

Players start with five cards in their hand. During game play, you have numerous different actions to choose from on your turn. You are attempting to collect different types of "cop" cards in order to "address" calls for service you choose to play. Solving or rather "resolving" calls for service results in points, depending on the difficulty of the call for service and the number/types of cops required. The winner is the first one to acquire 50 points worth of solved calls for service. The trick to that is you want to make sure you don't have a lot of unresolved calls in front of you because they count against your final score at the end!

The game incorporates dice as well for "shootout" cards. A simple mechanic in which the bad guys hit on a roll of "6" and the cop(s) hit on a "5" or "6". Winning shootouts get you points as well, losing shootouts costs you cops you have gathered.

There are also actions that allow you to recruit (steal) cops from other players (precincts), get extra cards for "grants", etc.

There is a lot going on in this game! You must keep an eye on your opponent's precinct, as well as try to manage your own.

Space Miners of the Remna Sector are cutthroat crews. They’ll do anything to score the next mother lode! When the government opened up a new Parsec for mining, they leapt at the chance to be the first in!
 Players are competing to harvest the most value out of Asteroids around the game board. Many asteroids are of hidden value and so player totals are secret, so you never know the true winner until the end!

The primary mechanic is drafting one-at-a-time, and then programming in "Commands" for your ship from a pool of Commands cards dealt anew each turn. Matching Commands can be assigned to "Special Commands" that do special (and mostly powerful) things. There are six ships to choose from at the start of the game, each with a different set of Special Commands. The gameboard is composed of modular squares, so the board changes every game.

item.description:
BattleAxe
by Nick Ryan

BattleAxe is an dark age battlefield warefare simulation tabletop game for 2 players (or 2 teams) that allows the players to use their strategic skills against each others armies. The main goal is to kill the opponent's King. Each army consists of 26 numbered men, 2 warhorses. Your army including axe-men, spearmen, swordsmen, archers, an engineer, horsemen and 1 king, all with different and balanced attributes. The fighting/attacking mechanism is an elegant 1 to 3 custom dice rolling system. Each player has the exact same army, similar to Chess, as to see which player really has superior strategic skills. Asymmetrical games can also be played with endless scenarios.

Each player has an "Army Map" sheet for his army which illustrates and keeps track of each warrior and warhorse. Each man in your army has his own health meter, skills, attributes, and even a place for the player to name them. This gives an unparalleled up-close-and-personal view from the battlefield. Engineers are a big part of the game, they can cut down trees, construct archer towers to enhance their attack range, walls, fire trenches and even make extra arrows for your archers. The concept of fire, from fire arrows and fire trenches symbolized by "wild fire" tiles are also a big part of the game. Fire can spread and take down your walls and towers which creates a real feel of the chaos of war.

It's who the better strategic commander is, not who can level up faster with fairy dust and gold coins.
It's dividing and concurring enraged enemy forces, not gathering grain for the winter.
It's swiftly destroying the opposing King and all his men to become the one true King of the battlefield.
It's BattleAxe.

Objective: be the first reaching target space (150) with a matching die roll
 - moving by turns -

basically a 'snake and ladders' approach with a few specialities:

In this lightweight fantasy game you get a random race (elf/undead/human/orc or demon) and a random saga (fight/duel/treasure/mist/crown).

The races all have a leader and 3-4 soldiers. Elf, undead and human have 1 character with a ranged attack.

Each saga has a different goal. Fight saga is a battle between all characters. Duel is just the leaders fighting it out. In Treasure saga you´ll fight to get the most treasure chests. Mist saga is a bit like chinese checkers were you´ll have to get your characters over on the other side and stop your opponent getting across. The crown saga is a battle to have most characters around the crown at games end. The end of the game is random. An hourglas will start at a given time, and when you draw a red hourglass the game ends. The board is also randomly drawn. You´ll start at opposite ends.

The 5 races has small variations in their stats(move/dodge/attack and defend) and a few characters can shoot, if line-of-sight is good. Each round you can move and attack (close combat or ranged). If you start your turn in combat you´ll have to dodge to be able to move away from combat. All characters have 1 life, so if a character is hit and fails to defend it is dead. You have to roll equal-to or above your stat.

Are you fast enough to be the first to the nucleus of the egg and getting the rest to leave you behind? Do not hesitate to challenge your friends, siblings or parents for this thrilling game about reproduction.

The first to reach the egg, win glory for himself and his posterity. However, this will not be easy because the road is littered with questions about men, women, pregnancy, love and so much more. As if this was not enough, you should really watch out for the other sperm. They will do everything for you to interfere with you at unexpected moments to attack and chase away!

The Game:
-has an exciting game concept about sex education, combined with scientific content
-lowers the threshold to talk about sexuality
-was developed by experienced authors in collaboration with Sensoa (Flemish Centre for Sexual Education)
-can be played with two to four players or teams

Spin the unpredictable wheel and follow the instructions. You must solve a question to the card you want to get or else the wheel decides your fate? Collect as soon as possible the entire family of one of the 7 vehicles and defeat your opponents. Who will win this game traffic?

It is a family game about road safety and traffic rules. It was read by the cell education of the Belgian Institute for Road Safety.

The game:
-promotes the knowledge of the highway
-allows young and old to think about road safety

simple 'Roll and Move' game

Legend of Nara: Battle Bugs was a line of electronic action figures based on insects inhabiting a ecologically ravaged planet and battling over energy sources.

The game itself pits the mechanical insects in an arena and are guided by a tether attached to the backside of each bug. The objective is to force the opponent out of the arena. There was also sold a separate racing track set where the bugs could be let loose to careen around the track.

Each unit comes with a core similar to a "nano bug" and an interchangeable insect costume. The shapes and weights of the costumes and cores could have an effect on each bugs speed and maneuverability.

Battle bugs were sold individually, in two bug packs and the racing arena track sold separately.

Product also included an MMO and a transforming action figure set.

With gameplay that supports two players in epic dice battles, DC Comics Dice Masters: Justice League lets players build their own version of the Justice League — or even the Legion of Doom!

item.description: Weekend in Vegas is a fun romp through America's playground. Games can range from a 12 turn game(short game) to a 48 turn game (an actual weekend in Vegas). Players choose a character at random who each have some special attributes that give them an edge. The object of Weekend in Vegas is to accumulate the most points before the end of the game. Players gain points by completing various objectives in the game such as seeing shows, riding attractions, dining out on the town and even partying at the clubs. As players scramble around town trying to get it all done they will find it will take cash, comps and even a little luck in order survive a Weekend in Vegas

Educational game for young children.

It suggests that an older sibling or relative reads out the cards.

A double word is one that consists ot two separate words making up one word. Clues, riddles really, are on each card. This is read out. The first player to call out the double word, wins a counter and the first to win 5 counters wins the game.

Example of a double word
One word = Salad
Other word = Öl
Together they make Salatöl (a dressing for salads).

The game consists of two sub-games.
In the first game players take the role of journalists and try to get to the sat-van as quick as possible in order to upload the three pictures they have to capture in this game. The pictures are all braunschweig-buildings or sites and have a UFO sighting on them.
This is a Malefiz kind of adaptation.

In the second part the game (backside of the board) journalists try to get the cover-story (word-guessing approach) before other players can beat them by running up the stairs of the publisher's office first.

This is a Malefiz kind of adaptation.

In the second part the game (backside of the board) journalists try to get the cover-story (word-guessing approach) before other players can beat them by running up the stairs of the publisher's office first.

This is a Malefiz kind of adaptation.

This is a Malefiz kind of adaptation.

This game consists of two sub-games. In the first game players take the role of journalists and try to get to the sat-van as quick as possible in order to upload the three pictures they have to capture in this game. The pictures are all Hagen-buildings or sites and have a UFO sighting on them.

Warzone Resurrection is a 32mm scale tabletop skirmish wargame for two or more players, each fielding units of warriors drawn from one of the mighty MegaCorporations of Mankind, the Brotherhood or its vile enemy, the Dark Legion. Warzone Resurrection is a fast paced, exciting and tactical miniature game created by Prodos Games Ltd. and Paraodox Entertainment.

The Warzone Resurrection project brings the tabletop game well and truly into the 21st century. Lovingly, we have taken essence and best bits from the game, art and prose of previous editions to produce all new miniatures, a background re-imagining (by Warzone mega-fan and writing genius, Andy Hoare) and an exciting innovative gaming system.

The gaming system involves both miniatures and cards. The minis are your skirmish force and the cards represent game resources, additional wargear, global and local effects on the battlefield etc.. In a real battle it is likely that a soldier wouldn't know his opponents wargear, whether they have grenades or a laser-sight for example. Both sides might be surprised by a Martian earthquake or Mercurian solar flare. The Venusian jungle cover you are in might be better (or worse) than you thought! War is rarely predictable, especially when it takes place on the planets, planetoids and asteroids of the solar system! All these and many more variables are represented by the cards you and your opponent play. Making Warzone Resurrection a truly novel, realistic and exciting tabletop miniature skirmish game!

The game brings 7 factions among the Bauhaus, Capital, Cybertronic, Mishima, Imperial, The Brotherhood and the Dark Legion

Re-implements:

 Warzone (first edition) 
 Warzone (second edition)

item.description:
Somewhere in the Caribbean lies a Secret World Order (S.W.O.R.D) base where scientists are creating a terrifying Doomsday Weapon.

In one hour the base will go into lockdown – no one will get in or out – and nothing will stand between the S.W.O.R.D and world domination.

The Peace Enforcing Nations (P.E.N) have dispatched their top agents to infiltrate the base. If they can acquire vital intelligence, the S.W.O.R.D's evil scheme may still be thwarted. They’ll need a combination of stealth and force to deal with guards, cameras, fiendish traps and the criminal mastermind known as ‘Claymore’, before the base is sealed.
 With just sixty minutes to save (or enslave) the world, it’s time to spy… or die trying!

Spy or Die Trying is a game for 2 to 4 players. One takes on the role of Base Defender (the Secret World Order); the others are Intruders (P.E.N agents) who play cooperatively against him.

The box set includes a full-color rule book, game board, die cut markers, secret agent profiles and dice. Card figures represent agents and minions in the game; metal miniatures are also available.

item.description:
A cooperative, card-driven game where players take on the role of ordinary citizens trying to drive of the little green men who are invading their town.

You will move from location to location, rescuing trapped citizens, battling aliens and facing unexpected events.

The objective is to reach the alien landing zone and defeat the alien army in a final, guns-blazing showdown.

GAMEPLAY
The basic mechanic involves building a deck from a random selection of the game's location cards. Each game will be a different experience as players will not know which locations will be available in each play.

Each player chooses a character template (a hero) which will determine the items, skills and abilities the player will have at their disposal.

One at a time, the location cards are revealed and resolved.

There will be events to manage, battles to fight and citizens to save. Heroes will find items as they go, putting these items to use in order to accomplish the task of defeating the aliens.

Combat is handled by rolling a pool of custom dice, which include hero dice, alien dice and friendly fire dice. By managing the results of each roll, the players will battle their way to victory and possibly, to defeat.

Iron-Core is primarily as a vehicle vs. vehicle combat system. Although infantry play an important role, they are not the primary focus of the game. A typical game will consist of one to five armored vehicles and, three to seven squads of infantry or support units.

The game is designed to play like a WWII simulation. Every effort was taken to use and distill actual WWII vehicle and combat data in the creation of the vehicle stats and game play. Unlike modern warfare, not every shot will hit its target and many hits will not penetrate your opponent’s armor and result in an instant kill. Two evenly matched vehicles may find themselves in an extended engagement, trading shot for shot until one finds a soft spot and makes the kill.

The decision to base the play style and game mechanics on a more antiquated technology was a conscious one, born from the desire to add more depth to the combat than a simple “Roll D6, four or better, you kill your target”. Vehicles, regardless of the manufacturer represent more of a financial investment than infantry units do. With this in mind, the number of large units required to play Iron-Core have been reduced as the vehicle and infantry survivability has been extended to a more descriptive and cinematic feel.

Our goal is to provide a game system that rewards tactics and punishes suicide runs. Applying bonuses and penalties based on unit position, unit formations, moral, and support fire and tactics; you will find that an inferior force can defeat a superior force with the application of some tactical forethought. Many of optional rules may slow play but highly recommended.

There are many game systems available, each have their own strengths, weaknesses and focus. If you are looking for a brigade level combat game, Iron-Core may not be the best choice. If you want a dynamic vehicle vs. vehicle combat system where having the biggest and the best does not equate to an “I win” button, then Iron-Core may be the game for you.

Simple, well-made trivia game for 'Canadian' families. No random die-rolling, just answer the trivia questions and progress across the game board on your choice of routes.

The goal is to be the first player to make a round trip on his/her route across Canada. Players who correctly answer questions in categories including General, Geography, History, and Arts for the 'Expert' players, move forward from city to city, across the board.

Family Edition cards have two sides - one with easier questions and the other with more difficult questions, allowing families of all ages to play together.

Includes 1,440 expert level questions in four categories (geography, history, arts, general) and 1,080 junior level questions in three categories (geography, history, general).

This game consists of two sub-games. In the first game players take the role of journalists and try to get to the sat-van as quick as possible in order to upload the three pictures they have to capture in this game. The pictures are all Essen-buildings or sites and have a UFO sighting on them.

This is a Malefiz kind of adaptation.

In the second part the game, journalists try to get the cover-story before the other players can by running up the stairs of the publisher trying to beat the others to his office.

This is a variant of Bohnanza using horses instead of beans; it is a licensed product for Wendy magazine, a German magazine focusing on horses. (There is also an animated TV show and so forth.)

from the Bohnanza entry:
As card games go, this one is quite revolutionary. Perhaps its oddest feature is that you cannot rearrange your hand, as you need to play the cards in the order that you draw them. The cards are colorful depictions of beans in various descriptive poses, and the object is to make coins by planting fields (sets) of these beans and then harvesting them. To help players match their cards up, the game features extensive trading and deal making.

The game is not identical to Bohnanza. The deck does not include an equivalent to the Garden Beans (6s), and from two to five of each type of horse are foals. When a foal is turned up as one of the cards to be traded, if there is only one player breeding that kind of horse they get it automatically. If a paddock has a foal on top when it is scored, it is worth nothing.

Other differences include the lack of the ability to buy a third paddock (field), the lack of a rule prohibiting scoring a paddock with a single horse under some circumstances, and the inclusion of rules for two players.

Northern Pacific is a luck-free railroad-building game for 3-5 players that lasts about twenty minutes. This game is in the genre of Iron Road/TransAmerica and SNCF/Paris Connection.

Players start the game with one large investment cube and three small investment cubes in hand. The game board shows the United States from Minnesota to Washington; game play starts in Minneapolis/St. Paul. On a turn, a player either places one of their cubes in a city (other than Seattle) that hasn't yet been reached by the train or builds track. If they build track, they choose one of the railroad lines exiting the city where the train is currently located and place a locomotive on it to show the current endpoint of the railroad line. Track has directional arrows on it, and a new train line can never move against the arrows or back to a city that the railroad has already visited.

When the railroad visits a city where players have placed investment cubes, they retrieve those cubes and take additional cubes from the supply: one new cube if they had a small cube in the city and two new cubes if they had a large cube.

When the railroad reaches Seattle, the round ends. Players tally the number of cubes in hand and records this number on the "good investments" track; they record the number of their cubes still on the game board on the "bad investments" track. They then reset the board as at the start of the game, then begin a new round. After three rounds, whoever has made the most good investments wins; if players are tied, then the tied player who has made the fewest bad investments wins.

You can play a single round of the game to determine a winner, if desired, or you can play new rounds with no recorded score, with a player winning the game if they win two rounds.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Game play is conventional round the board turns with risk and reward squares. The players hold shares in companies and gain or lose money whilst trying to get shares from other players. They can also buy and sell bull and bear positions to bet on rises and falls in company stocks.

The goal of the game is to acquire all the shares of a company, which causes the game to end, and have the most cash when the game ends.

Trenches is a fast-paced card game for two players, set in the trenches of late WWI.

The players will fight off for the best of 3 conflicts in order to win the campaign. Each conflict is decided using victory points, that are awarded by breaking a stand-still between two sides of trenched foes.

Each conflict represents a battle to hold 5 different objectives. To win the objectives, each player drafts a hand of 6 cards that will be played by turn (face down) on a chosen objective, until all players pass or finish their hand.

Then the players reveal the cards and start activating the special actions, in ascending order. Each side tallies the objectives they have obtained to determine if they broke the tie and won the conflict!

The game features a unique intense experience of drafting, deploying, deceiving and triumph!

Objective: be the first ending on space 66 (German coast) - starting in Friedichshafen
- moving by turns -
simple 'Roll & Move' game; cards are drawn to determine starting positions; ending on a marked space follow instructions glued inside the lid.

remarks:
should had been published ~1910

Objective: be the first collecting the key (01.01.2000) & reaching the centre of the board 
 - moving/acting by turns -
Each player moves according die roll with her/his hero, trying to make her/his way from the outer to the inner circles. During this path you move along spaces where you have to draw cards (action/events); collecting numbers/cyphers you are challenged/blocked by the so called 'Whytooky', a bad spirit. To master this spirit use your action cards.
remarks:
game was published short before millennium change - raising awareness for upcoming challenges. Game was produced by Ravensburger.

Ebenezer Scrooge's Eggnog Dash is a dice-rolling token collection game set in the world of Charles Dickens' Victorian England. The object of the game is to be the first player to collect all 6 eggnogs in your eggnog tray and retrieve the prize within the market shop (tin house).

Each player receives 18 game board pieces to build their path to the eggnog. It is up to each player to arrange the tiles in whatever order they would like. Each tile has a gold or silver 
back. Flip a gold tile over to take (1) eggnog from any other player when landed on. Flip a silver tile over for a lose one-turn event when landed on. Players can have any number of 
these gold or silver game pieces on the game board to vary the player experience. The more colored pieces played the more action during the game. The stealing of eggnog from other players gives the game more drama and fun.

Each player gets a market shop (tin house) to place at the end of the game pieces. The market shopis to be placed near the last tile leading to the eggnog stash. Place one Santa hat into each market shop. Players can also have someone place candy or even money in 
one or more shops during the pregame setup, making sure no one sees which shop has the extra prizes. This leads to a fun surprise bonus if the winning player also has extra treats in their market shop.
Players move via a dice-rolling mechanic, while play is influenced by pre-play tile placement and tile-specific actions. Players also may take opportunities to steal other players' token during play.

In Pop Goes Froggio a friend of the frog is selected by spinning a butterfly unit. After this all players at once try to find this friend by flipping over lily pads which are scattered around the room. The player who succeeds may launch the frog off his lily pad and try to catch it.
